Well, the principal problem or the principal thing that you have to understand is Fletcher only had three carriers.
These carriers not only had to support the landing, but they had to be ready to meet any Japanese counteroffensive, which could include Japanese carriers.
You're looking at an operation in 1942 that had three carriers.
The next major invasion--would've been in November 1943--had 19 carriers.
So Fletcher's doing things with very, very small forces.
And doing things often on the fly.
We forget just how quickly that Midway--excuse me, the Guadalcanal operation was thrown together.
Just within a month and a half, basically, after Midway.
I wonder, does Admiral Fletcher suffer by comparison?
His contemporaries included Bill Halsey, known as Bull Halsey to the public, never to anybody who actually knew him--nobody called him that to his face.
But Admiral William Halsey was one of the great heroes for many in the Second World War, highly aggressive and very colorful.
And the much less colorful, dour even, Raymond Spruance, who was brilliant.
Well, he definitely suffers because, first of all, he's not around very long.
He's relieved from command after the beginning of the Guadalcanal campaign.
And he's more or less sent to the North Pacific a little later in the war.
And he never got back into it.
In fact, there were histories done in 1943 that were sponsored by the Navy that actually failed to mention Fletcher even being at Midway, let alone being in command.
So something's going on behind the scenes with Fletcher.
What do you think it is?
I think it's a case of, first of all, he was the first one to command.
There was a lot of jealousy involved in that by certain people who thought, again, they could've done a much better job.
And the fact...
He was politically connected.
Well, he was.
Well, it's interesting, his important political connection was with Admiral Richardson, who was relieved before Pearl Harbor.
And so he really didn't have much political connection at that particular time.
He didn't get along with King.
And again, a lot of...
The new commander in chief of the US Navy.
Yes.
Exactly.
And a lot of it was due to misunderstanding.
They just didn't really know what was happening.
This happened so quickly--these campaigns happened so fast.
He was at sea for most of the first nine months of the war.
It's unbelievable the strain he must have suffered under.
But yet again, he did, I think, a very, very good job.
After the war, he never did anything to try to clear his reputation.
Well, one problem was he lost all of his papers.
In fact, a lot of his papers are sitting right now--for Coral Sea and Midway--are sitting in the Yorktown three and a half miles down.
They're probably in perfect shape; I'd love to see them, but I don't think I will.
And his papers for Guadalcanal were lost to him because he never had a chance to come back and get them.
And there are admirals who have written on Guadalcanal, like Admiral Richmond Kelly Turner, who did it on the basis of the papers they were able to save.
And he had kind of a choice to make when this all began happening.
He either was going to enjoy his retirement that he'd been waiting for or he was going to fight these battles for the rest of his life.
And he just simply chose to retire.
What did he do after his naval service?
He basically lived on a wonderful farm in Maryland, a colonial farm, and really enjoyed himself, worked in civic affairs.
He had a good life.
He lived until 1973, and he's buried in Arlington.
By all accounts, a very nice man, too.
Absolutely.
He was well-liked.
I was very fortunate to talk to the enlisted men who served with him in his particular flag complement, men who saw him every hour of the day and under all the different pressures and such.
They all thought the man was terrific.
Going back now and re-evaluating the career of Frank Jack Fletcher, this pioneer in the Second World War, how do you characterize his service?
What's so remarkable is that when he went on board an aircraft carrier the first time in January 1942, a month after Pearl Harbor, he'd never been on one before.
And he had to learn how to fight.
He had to know where to get the right advice and who to listen to, and how to do it.
And the carrier that he commanded, the Yorktown, was probably the best carrier the United States had in 1942, the most advanced in terms of doctrine on how it fought.
It's just ironic that it was the one that was sunk at Midway because even at Midway it by far was the best-handled ship.

But to be able to step in when you don't have the knowledge, intimate knowledge of a technology, and be able to pick it up as well as he did, not to lose your shirt, considering what he was facing--he was always facing odds--is terrific.
